content.statement: aku-004-mesenteric-arterial-anatomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Mesenteric-Ischemia that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-004-mesenteric-arterial-anatomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-004-mesenteric-arterial-anatomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-004-mesenteric-arterial-anatomy.

definitions_glossary.celiac_artery: First major anterior aortic branch, supplies foregut
definitions_glossary.SMA: Superior Mesenteric Artery - largest mesenteric vessel, supplies midgut
definitions_glossary.IMA: Inferior Mesenteric Artery - smallest mesenteric vessel, supplies hindgut
definitions_glossary.splanchnic_circulation: Combined blood flow to GI organs
definitions_glossary.watershed_areas: Regions at borders of arterial territories vulnerable to ischemia

branches.common_hepatic_artery: Supplies liver, divides into proper hepatic and gastroduodenal
branches.splenic_artery: Supplies spleen, pancreas, greater curvature of stomach

celiac_artery.surgical_importance: Rarely needs revascularization for ischemia if SMA patent

superior_mesenteric_artery.origin: Anterior aorta at L1, 1-2 cm below celiac
superior_mesenteric_artery.territory: Distal duodenum, entire jejunum and ileum, cecum, ascending and transverse colon
superior_mesenteric_artery.surgical_importance: Primary target for AMI treatment; carries largest blood volume

inferior_mesenteric_artery.origin: Anterior aorta at L3, 3-4 cm above bifurcation
inferior_mesenteric_artery.surgical_importance: Often sacrificed during AAA repair; collaterals usually adequate

celiac_to_SMA.clinical_significance: Most important collateral; allows SMA or celiac occlusion tolerance
celiac_to_SMA.direction_of_flow: Dependent on which vessel is stenosed

SMA_to_IMA.clinical_significance: Protects left colon when IMA sacrificed; may be absent in 5-10%
SMA_to_IMA.variant_absence: Missing arc of Riolan increases left colon ischemia risk during AAA repair

splenic_flexure.name: Griffiths point
splenic_flexure.location: Junction of SMA and IMA territories
splenic_flexure.clinical_significance: Vulnerable to ischemic colitis in low-flow states
splenic_flexure.frequency_of_ischemia: Most common site of ischemic colitis

rectosigmoid_junction.name: Sudeck's critical point
rectosigmoid_junction.location: Junction of IMA and internal iliac territories

celiac_SMA_common_trunk.significance: Single vessel occlusion affects both territories

replaced_hepatic_arteries.significance: Important during pancreatic and hepatobiliary surgery

blood_flow_physiology.oxygen_extraction: Normally low (25-30%); can increase with ischemia

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the origin, course, and territory of the three major mesenteric vessels
Identify key collateral pathways and their clinical importance
Recognize anatomic variants relevant to surgery
Understand watershed zones and their vulnerability to ischemia
clinical_pearls: The SMA's acute angle makes it a prime target for emboli
The 'two-vessel rule' exists because of robust collaterals
Check for arc of Riolan patency before IMA sacrifice during AAA repair
Splenic flexure and rectosigmoid are most vulnerable to low-flow ischemia
